title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can only be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Taxpayers must meet specific eligibility criteria to claim the HCTC. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. The credit is advanceable and can be received on a monthly basis. To claim the HCTC, taxpayers must be in one of two eligibility groups and not enrolled in certain types of health insurance. Eligible groups include recipients of benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program and individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). The Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. Workers must petition the U.S. Department of Labor to qualify for TAA benefits. Those certified for TAA benefits are eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) if they receive certain TAA benefits. The DOL investigation confirms workers' eligibility for TAA benefits, including the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) based on receiving specific TAA benefits like Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA). TRA provides cash payments for workers in TAA training who have exhausted unemployment insurance (UI) benefits, with a maximum of 130 weeks for UI and TRA combined. Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) is a wage supplement for workers aged 50 and older who secure qualified employment at a lower wage after being certified for TAA. RTAA pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years, with a maximum benefit of $10,000. Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance (ATAA) is a wage-insurance program similar to RTAA. ATAA existed before the recent TAA reauthorization, and a few workers may still qualify. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is available to individuals who receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program. Eligibility for the HCTC is limited to those who receive these specific benefits, not just job-search assistance. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is available to individuals who receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program. Eligibility for the HCTC is limited to those who receive these specific benefits. To receive a PBGC benefit, individuals must have worked for a firm with a defined-benefit pension plan insured and taken over by the PBGC. The PBGC takes over defined-benefit plans to protect participants' interests and pay pensions using plan assets and insurance reserves. Former workers eligible for PBGC-paid pensions can also receive the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old and not yet eligible for Medicare. The HCTC program provides tax credits to individuals receiving PBGC-paid pensions who are at least 55 years old but not yet eligible for Medicare. Eligibility limitations include not being enrolled in certain health plans or programs like Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, or State Children's Health. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must not be enrolled in Medicare Part A, Tricare, be incarcerated, or claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. The HCTC can be used for health insurance covering the individual, their spouse, and dependents. Individuals eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can use it for health insurance that covers their spouse and dependents. Family members may receive the HCTC for up to two years after certain events. Family members of eligible taxpayers can receive the HCTC for up to two years after specific events, such as the taxpayer becoming eligible for Medicare, divorce, or death. The tax credit can only be used for 11 categories of qualified health insurance, and individuals cannot claim it for any other type of coverage. The tax credit for qualified health insurance is limited to 11 categories of coverage, including COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by voluntary employees. The tax credit for qualified health insurance covers 11 categories of coverage, including COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by voluntary employees. Additionally, state-qualified health plans offer options such as state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, and coverage under a voluntary employees' beneficiary association. State-qualified health plans offer various coverage options, including state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, coverage under a plan for state employees, and other state-operated plans. State-qualified health plans provide coverage through state arrangements with private-sector health care purchasing pools or state-operated plans without federal financing. These plans must offer four consumer protections to qualifying individuals, defined as HCTC-eligible individuals with prior creditable coverage and no significant breaks in coverage. Qualifying individuals for state-qualified health plans must have three months of prior creditable coverage, no significant break in coverage, and are guaranteed issue with coverage not denied based on preexisting conditions. Premiums must be the same for qualifying individuals as for others, and benefits must be equal. State-qualified health plans must provide coverage to all qualifying applicants without denial based on preexisting conditions. Premiums and benefits for qualifying individuals must be equal to those for others. Certain types of coverage, such as accident or disability insurance, are not considered qualified health insurance. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program covers various insurance categories including accident or disability income insurance, liability insurance, workers' compensation insurance, and more. The IRS administers the program with involvement from federal and state agencies, with the Department of the Treasury responsible for administering advance payments on a monthly basis. The IRS administers the HCTC program with involvement from federal and state agencies. The Department of the Treasury is responsible for administering advance payments on a monthly basis, while DOL and PBGC help identify eligible individuals. DOL also coordinates the One-Stop Career Center system to provide information about benefits like the HCTC. The Department of Labor (DOL) coordinates the One-Stop Career Center system to assist job seekers and provide information about benefits like the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). State workforce agencies (SWAs) administer unemployment and Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) benefits, and DOL requests SWAs to mail HCTC information packets to eligible TAA beneficiaries, including an HCTC eligibility certificate. The Department of Labor (DOL) requests State Workforce Agencies (SWAs) to mail Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) information packets to eligible Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) beneficiaries. The IRS mails program kits to eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance to claim the tax credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The IRS mails program kits to eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance to claim the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. Taxpayers may choose to receive a portion of the credit through advance payments and the remainder after filing their returns. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Eligibility for other tax credits does not affect eligibility for the HCTC, and vice versa. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Eligibility for other tax credits does not affect eligibility for the HCTC, except for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. In 2014, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC for tax year 2013. The IRS published summary statistics in its 2014 Statistics of Income report regarding the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). For tax year 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. In 2016, preliminary data showed 13,015 e-filed tax returns claiming the credit. Taxpayers claiming the HCTC after the tax year ends must complete Form 8885 and attach it to Form 1040, including invoices and proof of payment for qualified health insurance. Taxpayers claiming the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) after the tax year ends must complete Form 8885 and attach it to Form 1040. They need to include invoices and proof of payment for qualified health insurance. The credit amount reduces taxes owed, and if it exceeds the amount owed, the excess is refunded to the taxpayer. To receive advance payments of the HCTC, individuals must register with the program and be enrolled in a qualified health insurance plan. Individuals register with the HCTC program to receive advance payments. They must be enrolled in a qualified health insurance plan and pay their share of the premium. Treasury then sends payment for the total premium to the health insurance plans.
